identificationModule.briefTitle: Muscle Activity of the Upper Limb Between Task-Specific and Robot Assisted Training Among Individuals Post Stroke
identificationModule.officialTitle: Differences in Muscle Activity and Fatigue of the Upper Limb Between Task-Specific Training and Robot Assisted Training Among Individuals Post Stroke

descriptionModule.briefSummary: The investigators compared the activity and fatigue of upper extremity muscles, pain levels, subject satisfaction levels, perceived exertion, and number of repetitions in Task-Specific Training (TST) compared with Robot-Assisted Training (RAT) in individuals post-stroke.
descriptionModule.detailedDescription: Twenty sub-acute post stroke subjects received one TST and one RAT. They marked the pain level in their paretic extremity before and after each session. Muscle activity levels and fatigue and number of repetitions were monitored during each session. The subjective assessment questionnaire of treatment and the Borg scale were administered post-session.

armGroups.label: Post stroke patients
interventionNames: Diagnostic Test: The RAT and The TST

interventions.name: The RAT and The TST
interventions.description: The RAT (ReoGo; Motorika Medical, Caesarea, Israel) The TST protocol included the conventional, repetitive, task-oriented training of the affected arm.

primaryOutcomes.description: The activity levels of electromyographic signal (in millivolts) will be averaged for the duration of the recording.
Fatigue expressed by calculation of the the difference between the median frequency in the first 5 minutes and last five minutes of a 30 minute session

eligibilityModule.eligibilityCriteria:
Inclusion Criteria:

* 18 to 85 year old individuals up to three months following stroke
* National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS) score 3-15
* Intact cognitive function
* mild to moderate weakness of the affected hand
* normal or corrected eyesight

Exclusion Criteria:

* neurological, cardio-vascular or orthopedic impairment, unrelated to the stroke, which restricts upper limb function
* a pace-maker
